title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing othersâ€™ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement gerardo.jrac@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozillaâ€™s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. title: Contributing to sAMRat
text: Thank interest contributing sAMRat â€” Shiny app antimicrobial resistance analysis. file gives brief, practical guide reporting issues, submitting changes, running basic checks locally.

title: Contributing to sAMRat
text: Fork repository create branch named X-feature/-short-desc X-fix/-short-desc. Replace X respective issue number. Make small, focused commits clear messages. Open pull request (PR) main branch. Describe problem, approach, testing ran.

title: Contributing to sAMRat
text: Use GitHub Issues page report bugs request features. Provide minimal reproducible example error messages screenshots.

title: Contributing to sAMRat
text: R package Shiny app. Follow standard R package practices possible. Keep changes small well-scoped.

title: Contributing to sAMRat
text: Prefer tidyverse style R code (e.g., consistent indentation, use pipes). Keep functions small documented roxygen2 comments.

title: Contributing to sAMRat
text: Tests live tests/testthat/. Add tests new behavior ensure existing tests still pass. Run tests locally R console :

title: Contributing to sAMRat
text: Run package check opening PR: modify exported functions add new ones, update roxygen documentation rebuild NAMESPACE:

title: Contributing to sAMRat
text: PR targets main branch (follow repo-specific branch policy) Adds updates tests applicable Passes devtools::check() new NOTE/ERRORs possible Includes entry NEWS.md changelog appropriate

title: Contributing to sAMRat
text: Please follow projectâ€™s code conduct (respectful constructive). project yet include CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md, follow GitHubâ€™s default community guidelines.

title: Contributing to sAMRat
text: questions help getting started, open issue email package maintainer listed DESCRIPTION. Thanks helping improve sAMRat â€” contributions welcome appreciated!

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: document describes architecture structure sAMRat (Shiny Antimicrobial Resistance Analysis Tool) package. Understanding architecture help contributors navigate codebase implement new features effectively.

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: sAMRat package follows standard R package conventions additional structure Shiny application:
code: sAMRat/ â”œâ”€â”€ R/                      # R functions and core logic â”‚   â””â”€â”€ create_amr_obj.R    # Core AMR object creation â”œâ”€â”€ inst/                   # Installed files â”‚   â””â”€â”€ shiny/              # Shiny application files â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ app.R           # Main Shiny app â”‚       â””â”€â”€ modules/        # Shiny modules â”‚           â”œâ”€â”€ modal_help.R â”‚           â”œâ”€â”€ modal_settings.R â”‚           â”œâ”€â”€ tab_data.R â”‚           â””â”€â”€ tab_results.R â”œâ”€â”€ man/                    # Documentation (auto-generated) â”œâ”€â”€ tests/                  # Unit tests â”‚   â””â”€â”€ testthat/ â”œâ”€â”€ vignettes/              # Long-form documentation â”œâ”€â”€ DESCRIPTION             # Package metadata â”œâ”€â”€ NAMESPACE               # Exported functions â””â”€â”€ README.md               # Main documentation

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: R/ directory contains core R functions provide underlying functionality: create_amr_obj.R: main function creating AMR-compatible data objects. function bridges gap user data AMR packageâ€™s expected format. functions can used independently Shiny application, making package useful interactive programmatic use cases.

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: Shiny application organized using modular structure maintainability scalability:

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: app.R: entry point Shiny application. coordinates UI server logic, initializing modules setting application structure.

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: application uses Shiny modules separate concerns create reusable components: tab_data.R: Handles data upload, import, initial processing. module manages: File upload functionality Data preview Column mapping interface tab_results.R: Manages analysis results visualizations. Features include: Statistical summaries Interactive plots Export functionality modal_help.R: Provides contextual help documentation within application modal_settings.R: Manages application settings user preferences modular architecture allows : - Easy maintenance debugging - Reusable components across different parts application - Clear separation concerns - Simplified testing

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: package includes unit tests using testthat framework: Tests located tests/testthat/ test file follows naming convention test-*.R Currently includes tests create_amr_obj() function run tests:

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: Documentation managed : man/: Auto-generated function documentation using roxygen2 Getting Started guide Architecture overview (document) Contributing guidelines

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: typical data flow application: Data Upload â†’ User uploads raw microbiological data Data Mapping â†’ User maps columns AMR-expected format Object Creation â†’ create_amr_obj() creates AMR-compatible object Analysis â†’ AMR package functions process data Visualization â†’ Results displayed interactive plots tables Export â†’ Results exported various formats

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: AMR: foundation package antimicrobial resistance analysis dplyr: Data manipulation transformation ggplot2: Data visualization shiny: Interactive web application framework

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: testthat: Unit testing framework roxygen2: Documentation generation devtools: Development tools pkgdown: Website generation

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: sAMRat architecture follows key principles: Modularity: Components separated modules maintainability Reusability: Core functions can used independently Shiny app User-Friendly: Interactive interface reduces learning curve AMR analysis Extensibility: New features modules can easily added Standards Compliance: Follows R package development best practices Testing: Comprehensive test coverage reliability

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: adding new features sAMRat: new analyses: Add functions R/ directory appropriate documentation UI components: Create new modules inst/shiny/modules/ documentation: Add vignettes explain complex features testing: Add corresponding tests tests/testthat/ Always follow existing code style patterns maintain consistency.

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: application designed handle typical clinical laboratory datasets Data sampling previews Lazy loading strategies Progress indicators long-running operations Caching computed results

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: Potential areas expansion: Integration additional AMR analysis packages Database connectivity large datasets RESTful API programmatic access Docker containerization easy deployment Additional visualization options Batch processing capabilities

title: sAMRat Architecture
text: proposing architectural changes: Open issue discuss change Consider backward compatibility Update document reflect changes Ensure tests pass Add new tests new components See Contributing Guide details.

title: Getting Started with sAMRat
text: Welcome sAMRat (Shiny Antimicrobial Resistance Analysis Tool)! package provides interactive Shiny application designed facilitate antimicrobial resistance (AMR) data analysis reporting. application builds powerful AMR package provide intuitive interface : Uploading mapping microbiological datasets Performing comprehensive AMR data analysis Generating visualizations statistical reports Exporting results use

title: Getting Started with sAMRat
text: Currently, sAMRat available CRAN, â€™ll need install GitHub repository.

title: Getting Started with sAMRat
text: Clone repository terminal/shell: load directly using devtools IDE (e.g., RStudio) console:
code: git clone https://github.com/Gero1999/sAMRat if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)) {   install.packages("devtools") } devtools::load_all()

text: Make sure required dependencies installed:

what: Create an AMR-ready object by converting selected columns â€” create_amr_obj
title: Create an AMR-ready object by converting selected columns â€” create_amr_obj
text: helper converts specified columns data.frame AMR-friendly types using [AMR] package (example `.mo()`, `.sir()`, `.mic()`, `.disk()`) collects metadata microorganisms antimicrobials. also attempt coerce date column `Date` using common formats can optionally filter first isolate per subject microorganism. helper converts specified columns data.frame AMR-friendly types using [AMR] package (example `.mo()`, `.sir()`, `.mic()`, `.disk()`) collects metadata microorganisms antimicrobials. also attempt coerce date column `Date` using common formats can optionally filter first isolate per subject microorganism.

title: Create an AMR-ready object by converting selected columns â€” create_amr_obj
code: create_amr_obj(   df,   mo_col = NULL,   sir_cols = NULL,   mic_cols = NULL,   disk_cols = NULL,   date_col = NULL,   subject_col = NULL,   filter_first_isolate = FALSE )  create_amr_obj(   df,   mo_col = NULL,   sir_cols = NULL,   mic_cols = NULL,   disk_cols = NULL,   date_col = NULL,   subject_col = NULL,   filter_first_isolate = FALSE )

title: Create an AMR-ready object by converting selected columns â€” create_amr_obj
text: df data.frame containing raw isolate susceptibility data. mo_col Character (single) name microorganism column `df`. provided, values coerced `.mo()` microorganism metadata returned. sir_cols Character vector column names containing S//R results. found column coerced `.sir()`. mic_cols Character vector column names containing MIC results. found column coerced `.mic()`. disk_cols Character vector column names containing disk diffusion results. found column coerced `.disk()`. date_col Character (single) name date column. function try common formats coerce column `Date`. subject_col Character (single) name column used subject/patient identifier. provided `SUBJID` factor column added returned data. filter_first_isolate Logical, `TRUE` data filtered first isolate per subject x microorganism (earliest date). function uses `dplyr::filter()` internal helper fall back returning unfiltered data error.

title: Create an AMR-ready object by converting selected columns â€” create_amr_obj
text: named list least:   * `data`: transformed `data.frame`.   * `mo` (optional): list `naming`, `traits`, `taxonomy`,     `details` data.frames microorganism column.   * `ab` (optional): list `group`, `details`, `atc`, `tradenames`     `loinc` information antibiotic columns. named list least:   * `data`: transformed `data.frame`.   * `mo` (optional): list `naming`, `traits`, `taxonomy`,     `details` data.frames microorganism column.   * `ab` (optional): list `group`, `details`, `atc`, `tradenames`     `loinc` information antibiotic columns.

title: Create an AMR-ready object by converting selected columns â€” create_amr_obj
text: returned object list least `data` element (transformed data.frame). microorganism column provided, `mo` sub-list naming, traits, taxonomy details included. antibiotic columns provided corresponding `ab` sub-list returned group details information. function wraps number convenience conversions   [AMR] package. uses `try()`/`tryCatch()` several places   avoid hard failures partial unexpected inputs. returned object list least `data` element (transformed data.frame). microorganism column provided, `mo` sub-list naming, traits, taxonomy details included. antibiotic columns provided corresponding `ab` sub-list returned group details information. function wraps number convenience conversions   [AMR] package. uses `try()`/`tryCatch()` several places   avoid hard failures partial unexpected inputs.

title: Create an AMR-ready object by converting selected columns â€” create_amr_obj
code: # Minimal example (requires the AMR package): if (requireNamespace("AMR", quietly = TRUE)) {   df <- data.frame(     mo = c("Escherichia coli", "Staphylococcus aureus"),     AMP = c("R", "S"),     date = c("2020-01-01", "2020-01-02"),     id = c("p1", "p2"),     stringsAsFactors = FALSE   )   create_amr_obj(df, mo_col = "mo", sir_cols = "AMP", date_col = "date", subject_col = "id") } #> $data #>                      mo AMP       date id SUBJID #> 1      Escherichia coli   R 2020-01-01 p1     p1 #> 2 Staphylococcus aureus   S 2020-01-02 p2     p2 #>  #> $mo #> $mo$naming #>                      mo              fullname     short               current #> 1      Escherichia coli      Escherichia coli   E. coli      Escherichia coli #> 2 Staphylococcus aureus Staphylococcus aureus S. aureus Staphylococcus aureus #>  #> $mo$traits #>                      mo    gram_stain pathogenicity     oxygen_tolerance #> 1      Escherichia coli Gram-negative    Pathogenic facultative anaerobe #> 2 Staphylococcus aureus Gram-positive    Pathogenic facultative anaerobe #>       type #> 1 Bacteria #> 2 Bacteria #>  #> $mo$taxonomy #>                      mo species          genus             family #> 1      Escherichia coli    coli    Escherichia Enterobacteriaceae #> 2 Staphylococcus aureus  aureus Staphylococcus  Staphylococcaceae #>              order               class         phylum  kingdom #> 1 Enterobacterales Gammaproteobacteria Pseudomonadota Bacteria #> 2    Caryophanales             Bacilli      Bacillota Bacteria #>  #> $mo$details #>                                          mo     gbif #> Escherichia coli           Escherichia coli 11286021 #> Staphylococcus aureus Staphylococcus aureus     <NA> #>                                                                      url #> Escherichia coli           https://lpsn.dsmz.de/species/escherichia-coli #> Staphylococcus aureus https://lpsn.dsmz.de/species/staphylococcus-aureus #>  #> $mo$columns #> $mo$columns$mo #> [1] "mo" #>  #>  #>  #> $ab #> $ab$group #>   col  ab       name                    group #> 1 AMP AMP Ampicillin Beta-lactams/penicillins #>                                atc_group1                         atc_group2 #> 1 Beta-lactam antibacterials, penicillins Penicillins with extended spectrum #>  #> $ab$details #>    ab ab_val ddd_oral_amount ddd_oral_units ddd_iv_amount ddd_iv_units #> 1 AMP    AMP               2              g             6            g #>  #> $ab$atc #> [1] "J01CA01"  "QJ01CA01" "QJ51CA01" "QS01AA19" "S01AA19"  #>  #> $ab$tradenames #>  [1] "adobacillin"     "alpen"
